title: Permits different standards relating to approval of the solid waste management plan in N.Y. city
summary: Permits different standards to be employed for department of environmental conservation approval of solid waste management plans of cities of 1 million or more population submitted to it; ensures that municipalities with a population of one million or more have the flexibility to determine the most efficient method of implementing local recycling programs.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2563

TITLE OF BILL:
An act to amend the general municipal law and the environmental conser-
vation law, in relation to the solid waste management plan in cities
with a population of one million or more

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
This bill amends § 27-0107 of the Environmental Conservation Law and
120-aa of the General Municipal Law to insure that municipalities with a
population of one million or more have the flexibility to determine the
most efficient method of implementing local recycling programs.

JUSTIFICATION:
The 1988 Solid Waste Management Act amended § 120-aa of the General
Municipal Law to require municipalities to adopt by September 1, 2002, a
local source separation law for recyclable, reusable or other separable
components of the solid waste stream for which economic markets for
alternate uses exist. In § 27-0106(2) of the Environmental Conservation
Law, the Legislature clearly indicated that localities are to have
primary responsibility for implementing waste reduction and recycling
programs.

In response to the 1988 Act's requirement that municipalities adopt
recycling laws by September 1, 1992, the New York City Council, in April
of 1989, enacted Local Law 19 which established the framework for the
City's recycling program. Local Law 19 required that the City's residen-
tial recycling program, which at the time of Local Law 19's enactment
was in the pilot stage, be expanded citywide in stages. It is our under-
standing that § 120-aa allows a reasonable time for implementation of
the recycling program. This bill clarifies that the City has until
September 1, 2002 to provide for the mandatory separation of recyclable,
reusable or, other components of solid waste for which economic markets
for alternate uses exist.

In addition, Local Law 19 requires commercial sector recycling. In June
1991, commercial recycling rules issued pursuant to Local Law 19 went
into effect. These rules require the recycling of several materials by
commercial generators by November 29, 1991 (high-grade office paper,
corrugated cardboard, metals, and certain components of construction and
demolition debris) The rules also require the recycling of additional
materials over the next few years. While Local Law 19 requires source
separation of residential waste, it does not similarly require source
separation of commercial waste. Section 16-306 of Local Law 19 permits
generators of private-carter collected waste either to source separate
designated recyclable materials or to arrange for the post-collection
separation of those materials.  Although it may be argued that local Law
19 complies with General Municipal Law §120-aa by insuring that the
policy goals of recycling are achieved and provides for a substantial
amount of source separation, this bill amends § 120-aa and § 27-0107 to
insure that post-collection separation is an option available in New

York City. In order for recycling to be successful, the City needs the
flexibility to try various approaches to recyclable collection. For many
businesses throughout the City, post-collection separation for certain
materials may make better environmental and economic sense. Source-sepa-
ration may require multiple collections and, therefore, multiple trucks.
The environmental benefits from post-collection separation may include
potentially less truck traffic on already crowded city streets, and less
pollution, noise, and energy usage through the avoidance of such traf-
fic.  Additionally, smaller businesses, which comprise a significant
portion of the City's commercial sector, would be spared the financial
burden of paying for multiple collections and of acquiring space for the
storage of source separated materials. The separation and collection
options available to the City must be flexible in order to accommodate
the unique circumstances of the various sectors required to implement
recycling programs. Therefore, § 27-0107 of the Environmental Conserva-
tion Law and § 120-aa of the General Municipal Law should be amended to
insure that the City have flexibility to determine the most economically
and environmentally efficient method of implementing the State's recycl-
ing mandates by September 1, 2002.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
None.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediately.
